rev.diff:
Line 27: Line 27:
Abbas began his organizing work under the [[Hosni Mubarak|Mubarak regime]], when unions were dominated by the state-approved [[Egyptian Trade Union Federation]] (ETUF). He participated in a strike at the steel works in [[Helwan]], Egypt.<ref name="towardfreedom1"/> Abbas' relationship with Mubarak's regime was tense and marked by conflicts with the government and arrests.<ref name="towardfreedom1"/>
Abbas began his organizing work under the [[Hosni Mubarak|Mubarak regime]], when unions were dominated by the state-approved [[Egyptian Trade Union Federation]] (ETUF). He participated in a strike at the steel works in [[Helwan]], Egypt.<ref name="towardfreedom1"/> Abbas' relationship with Mubarak's regime was tense and marked by conflicts with the government and arrests.<ref name="towardfreedom1"/>
â
In 2005 Abbas was critical of how workers rights were being addressed in the political dialogue. He said, "Unfortunately, the labour movement's democratic demands are absent from the agenda of change called for by the opposition. Even the political parties that are close to workers' circles -- such as the Tagammu and Nasserist parties -- are only interested now in the laws that regulate political participation and professional syndicates." He told [[Al-Ahram]], "Political movements that once upheld the interests of the working class based themselves on public sector workers, most of whom have been liquidated through early retirement schemes...the current environment where workers see people taking on the state and putting up a fight has created a situation in which we can see renewed labour activism of the sort now taking place...I do not think that such a movement would have been possible if it were not for the current movement for political reform."<ref>http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2005/740/eg10.htm</ref>
+
In 2005 Abbas was critical of how workers rights were being addressed in the political dialogue. He said, "Unfortunately, the labour movement's democratic demands are absent from the agenda of change called for by the opposition. Even the political parties that are close to workers' circles -- such as the Tagammu and Nasserist parties -- are only interested now in the laws that regulate political participation and professional syndicates." He told [[Al-Ahram]], "Political movements that once upheld the interests of the working class based themselves on public sector workers, most of whom have been liquidated through early retirement schemes...the current environment where workers see people taking on the state and putting up a fight has created a situation in which we can see renewed labour activism of the sort now taking place...I do not think that such a movement would have been possible if it were not for the current movement for political reform."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2005/740/eg10.htm |title=Al-Ahram Weekly | Egypt | May Day and the absent actor |publisher=Weekly.ahram.org.eg |date=2005-05-04 |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref>
â
In 2005 Abbas criticized the negotiations in the [[Esco]] workers' protest. He noted that clause 69 of the labor contract, which stipulated workers could be fired if they fail to perform "essential duties", was broad enough to permit random firings.<ref>http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2005/743/eg42.htm</ref>
+
In 2005 Abbas criticized the negotiations in the [[Esco]] workers' protest. He noted that clause 69 of the labor contract, which stipulated workers could be fired if they fail to perform "essential duties", was broad enough to permit random firings.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2005/743/eg42.htm |title=Al-Ahram Weekly | Egypt | 'A partial victory' |publisher=Weekly.ahram.org.eg |date=2005-05-25 |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref>
â
In June 2005 Abbas commented on legal issues dealing with the Al-Amrya Weaving and Textile Company workers have ended their strike. He said, "The distinction between public and private sector workers will in any case become irrelevant, sooner or later, given that the entire public sector is on the block. What is important in this case is that the Unified Labour Law (12) of 2003 doesn't differentiate between private and public sector workers. Misr Al-Amrya cannot legally argue on the basis of state workers' rights to base salary increments versus private sector workers' non-rights. Which is why, in the end, the company did eventually comply."<ref>http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2005/749/eg9.htm</ref>
+
In June 2005 Abbas commented on legal issues dealing with the Al-Amrya Weaving and Textile Company workers have ended their strike. He said, "The distinction between public and private sector workers will in any case become irrelevant, sooner or later, given that the entire public sector is on the block. What is important in this case is that the Unified Labour Law (12) of 2003 doesn't differentiate between private and public sector workers. Misr Al-Amrya cannot legally argue on the basis of state workers' rights to base salary increments versus private sector workers' non-rights. Which is why, in the end, the company did eventually comply."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2005/749/eg9.htm |title=Al-Ahram Weekly | Egypt | Political spin-off effects |publisher=Weekly.ahram.org.eg |date=2005-07-06 |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref>
â
In July 2005 Abbas was attacked by plain-clothes Egyptian security forces while demonstrating against human rights abuses by the Mubarak's regime. He was badly wounded.<ref>http://www.fpif.org/articles/bombings_and_repression_in_egypt_underscore_failures_in_us_anti-terrorism_strategy</ref>
+
In July 2005 Abbas was attacked by plain-clothes Egyptian security forces while demonstrating against human rights abuses by the Mubarak's regime. He was badly wounded.<ref>{{cite web|last=Zunes |first=Stephen |url=http://www.fpif.org/articles/bombings_and_repression_in_egypt_underscore_failures_in_us_anti-terrorism_strategy |title=Bombings and Repression in Egypt Underscore Failures in U.S. Anti-Terrorism Strategy |publisher=FPIF |date=2005-08-11 |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref>
â
In November 2006 Abbas dismissed the significance of General Federation of Trade Unions (GFTU) elections arguing that public sector industrial workers overseen by the GFTU were increasingly few. He recommended switching focus to uninionized private sector workers: "The minister of investment has openly stated that except for four companies the little that remains of the industrial public sector is for sale...the real battle is to fight for trade union pluralism, to build a new and independent trade union structure."<ref>http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2006/818/eg4.htm</ref>
+
In November 2006 Abbas dismissed the significance of General Federation of Trade Unions (GFTU) elections arguing that public sector industrial workers overseen by the GFTU were increasingly few. He recommended switching focus to uninionized private sector workers: "The minister of investment has openly stated that except for four companies the little that remains of the industrial public sector is for sale...the real battle is to fight for trade union pluralism, to build a new and independent trade union structure."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2006/818/eg4.htm |title=Al-Ahram Weekly | Egypt | Battling over a dead horse |publisher=Weekly.ahram.org.eg |date=2006-11-07 |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref>
â
In 2007, after Mahala Al-Kobra textile workers threatened to impeach him for allegedly staging fraudulent union elections in October 2006, General Federation of Trade Unions (GFTU) President Hussein Megawer denounced Abbas as a "foreign-funded agent" on the satellite TV channel Dream 2. Megawer argued that CTUWS should be shut down; closure of the Naja Hamadi branch followed almost immediately.<ref>http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2007/843/eg4.htm</ref>
+
In 2007, after Mahala Al-Kobra textile workers threatened to impeach him for allegedly staging fraudulent union elections in October 2006, General Federation of Trade Unions (GFTU) President Hussein Megawer denounced Abbas as a "foreign-funded agent" on the satellite TV channel Dream 2. Megawer argued that CTUWS should be shut down; closure of the Naja Hamadi branch followed almost immediately.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2007/843/eg4.htm |title=Al-Ahram Weekly | Egypt | Workers remain undaunted |publisher=Weekly.ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref>
â
In 2010 Abbas criticized proposals to postpone trade union elections. Abbas criticized the role of the ETUF as "a governmental institution, not a federation of genuine trade unions. Nor does it represent Egypt's workers in any way."<ref>http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/227915</ref> Abbas also noted the practice of elected officials busing in members of their constituency to vote.<ref>http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/227915</ref>
+
In 2010 Abbas criticized proposals to postpone trade union elections. Abbas criticized the role of the ETUF as "a governmental institution, not a federation of genuine trade unions. Nor does it represent Egypt's workers in any way."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/227915 |title=ETUF makes bid to rally workers behind president, regime | Al-Masry Al-Youm: Today's News from Egypt |publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date=2009-12-16 |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref> Abbas also noted the practice of elected officials busing in members of their constituency to vote.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/227915 |title=ETUF makes bid to rally workers behind president, regime | Al-Masry Al-Youm: Today's News from Egypt |publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date=2009-12-16 |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref>
==Egyptian revolution of 2011==
==Egyptian revolution of 2011==
Abbas made an appeal for a new federation of trade unions from [[Tahrir Square]] during the revolution. He said, âOn January 30th we met with representative of other independent trade union organizations and we discussed forming a new federation. We then made an announcement in Tahrir square, calling for a new federation. But at the time we had no idea what would happen. Since then this call has been responded to by the workers. The challenge now that the revolution has succeeded is to be able to build a society of social justice.â<ref name="towardfreedom1"/>
Abbas made an appeal for a new federation of trade unions from [[Tahrir Square]] during the revolution. He said, âOn January 30th we met with representative of other independent trade union organizations and we discussed forming a new federation. We then made an announcement in Tahrir square, calling for a new federation. But at the time we had no idea what would happen. Since then this call has been responded to by the workers. The challenge now that the revolution has succeeded is to be able to build a society of social justice.â<ref name="towardfreedom1"/>
â
In February 2011 Abbas criticized the elections in federation syndicates for being corrupted with fraud. He said, "There are 116 verdicts of administrative court annulling the last union elections and we believe members of the federation were involved in acts of violence against the protesters in Tahrir.â Abbas recommended creating independent syndicates, saying "We will do as our grandfathers did before 1952 when the first unions were created in Egypt.â<ref>http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContentPrint/3/0/6383/Business/0/Revolution-fuels-Egypt-labour-movement-.aspx</ref>
+
In February 2011 Abbas criticized the elections in federation syndicates for being corrupted with fraud. He said, "There are 116 verdicts of administrative court annulling the last union elections and we believe members of the federation were involved in acts of violence against the protesters in Tahrir.â Abbas recommended creating independent syndicates, saying "We will do as our grandfathers did before 1952 when the first unions were created in Egypt.â<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContentPrint/3/0/6383/Business/0/Revolution-fuels-Egypt-labour-movement-.aspx |title=Ahram Online - Revolution fuels Egypt labour movement |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date=2011-02-25 |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref>
â
In May 2011 Abbas celebrated [[May Day]], the international socialist commemoration of workers' rights reform in the United States. Abbas deemed that year's celebrations âhistoricâ for marking a break from the ETUF. Abbas also praised the then newly formed Egyptian Federation of Independent Trade Unions (EITUF). May Day celebrations focused on the free will of Egyptian workers to form independent trade unions, free from state control, and the dismantling of the ETUF.<ref>http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/11128/Egypt/Politics-/Egyptians-celebrate-first-May-Day-since-popular-up.aspx</ref>
+
In May 2011 Abbas celebrated [[May Day]], the international socialist commemoration of workers' rights reform in the United States. Abbas deemed that year's celebrations âhistoricâ for marking a break from the ETUF. Abbas also praised the then newly formed Egyptian Federation of Independent Trade Unions (EITUF). May Day celebrations focused on the free will of Egyptian workers to form independent trade unions, free from state control, and the dismantling of the ETUF.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/11128/Egypt/Politics-/Egyptians-celebrate-first-May-Day-since-popular-up.aspx |title=Egyptians celebrate first May Day since popular uprising - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref>
In June 2011, Abbas was co-filer of a lawsuit calling for the dissolution of the state-controlled ETUF. The suit called for "sequestration of the ETUF headquarters, buildings, its Workers' University, cultural institute, hospitals and clinics" as well as "barring the ETUF from representing Egypt's workers or unions at international conferences".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/468158 |title=Legal battle against Mubarak's trade union federation begins | Al-Masry Al-Youm: Today's News from Egypt |publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date=2011-06-14 |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref>
In June 2011, Abbas was co-filer of a lawsuit calling for the dissolution of the state-controlled ETUF. The suit called for "sequestration of the ETUF headquarters, buildings, its Workers' University, cultural institute, hospitals and clinics" as well as "barring the ETUF from representing Egypt's workers or unions at international conferences".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/468158 |title=Legal battle against Mubarak's trade union federation begins | Al-Masry Al-Youm: Today's News from Egypt |publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date=2011-06-14 |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref>
